docs.lead_paragraph: One of the classic symptoms of autism is difficulty recognizing people's faces, one reason, perhaps, why people with autism show so little interest in other people. Now, researchers at Yale say they may have a better understanding of the problem, as a result of brain scans.
docs.abstract: Researchers at Yale say they as result of brain scans, they have better understanding of why people with autism show so little interest in other people; one of classic symptoms of autism is difficulty recognizing people's faces (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Major medical organizations often frown on smaller hospitals that perform elective angioplasty, saying that the procedure to unclog arteries and reduce the risk of heart attacks is so delicate it should be done only at institutions where it is performed regularly. But a new study suggests benefits to loosening that policy to allow patients in rural areas better access to the treatment. The guidelines are not binding, but they can influence state regulations governing what procedures hospitals can perform.

headline.main: When Small Hospitals Fix Big Blockages

docs.abstract: Study suggests there are benefits in allowing smaller hospitals in rural areas to perform elective angioplasty, procedure to unclog arteries and reduce risk of heart attacks; major medical orgns often frown on smaller hospitals performing angioplasty, saying procedure is so delicate that it should be done only at institutions where it is performed regularly (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: How good are Prozac and its relatives at treating depression? If the claims made by some researchers over the last few years are given any credence, the drugs, despite their popularity, are little better than dummy pills in driving away despair.

headline.main: More Fuel For Debate On Prozac

docs.abstract: Erica Goode assesses debate over how good are Prozac and its relatives in treating depression; some researchers contend that drugs, despite their popularity, are little better than dummy pills in driving away despair; other researchers challenge this view, finding that such drugs do offer relief from depression (M)
docs.snippet: How good are Prozac and its relatives at treating depression?    If the claims made by some researchers over the last few years are given any credence, the drugs, despite their popularity, are little better than dummy pills in driving away despair.

docs.lead_paragraph: Quan Phu, the fitness manager of 24-Hour Fitness, a health club in Huntington Beach, Calif., likes to be precise about his workouts. For instance, he knows that his run to Sunset Beach is five miles and 7,610 steps, thanks to the new pedometer he wears snapped to his waistband. But this is not the old style pedometer: the model he uses does more than simply measure footfalls. It also computes calories burned and average speed, records data for the current and previous week and contains fitness programs.

headline.main: A Fitness Industry, With Gadgets Galore

docs.abstract: Technology wave has hit exercise equipment, and manufacturers flood market with gadgets for fitness buffs; computer chip transforms what fitness companies can put out there; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Eileen Cafasso's conversation with her patient was expansive, touching on his taste for turnip paste, his number of daily bananas, his self-diagnosed addiction to cheese. There was time for him to ask about a particular blood pressure drug he had read about, and for her to ask how he had spent his holidays. There was no watching of wristwatches.

headline.main: Like a Doctor's Office, With a Little More Time

docs.abstract: Nurse practitioners are seen gaining in acceptance; nurse practitioners are ble to prescribe medicine and, in some states, admit patients to hospital; they pride themselves on their ability to spend more time with patients, focusing on illness prevention; nurses' practice was focus of study published in January in Journal of American Medical Assn; study finds no significant differences in quality of care received by patients randomly assigned either to doctors or nurse practitioners; photo of Eileen Cafasso, nurse pracititioner in Manhattan (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: People with social anxiety disorder, a common psychiatric ailment, realize they have a problem but often fail to seek treatment because of embarrassment or lack of resources, a study has found. The study, in The American Journal of Psychiatry, said more should be done to build public awareness of the treatments and to educate health care professionals.

headline.main: Few Seek Help for Extreme Social Fears

docs.lead_paragraph: By some estimates, as many as 30,000 back operations a year are performed in the United States to remove damaged disks and fuse the spine back together to reduce a patient's lower back pain. In many cases, a new study argues, doctors would be better off shifting their focus to their patients' state of mind.

headline.main: Of Suffering, Coping and Damaged Disks

docs.abstract: Researchers at Stanford say they found little correlation between tears commonly found in poeple's vertebral disks and their level of lower back pain; study argues that doctors would be better off shifting their focus to their patients' state of mind; as many as 30,000 back operations a year are performed in United States remove damaged disks and fuse the spine back together to reduce patient's lower back pain (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A young woman in psychotherapy recovered the memory that at age 13 she was raped by her teacher, became pregnant and underwent an abortion. No corroborating evidence for this event existed. In fact, the woman had not reached menarche until 15, so the pregnancy was medically impossible. Still, she filed criminal charges against the teacher, who had to spend his life savings to defend himself against the false accusation. Eventually, the court ruled that recovery of a repressed memory lacked sufficient scientific foundation to be admissible evidence.

headline.main: Memories of Things That Never Were

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on 'false memory syndrome,' so-called recovered memories, particularly those involving allegations of childhood sexual abuse by a parent or other close relative, teacher or friend; notes such recovered memories are often fictions induced by concerted efforts of therapist who fosters a belief thta becomes so deeply held it seems like a real memory; 'false memory syndrome' has resulted in many family tragedies: alienation of children from parents, loss of jobs, ostracism and divorces (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The young woman walked into my office and plopped herself sullenly into a vinyl chair. ''I want a referral to a chiropractor,'' she said. Judging from her face, she was in no mood for small talk. She was healthy and angry. Earlier that morning, she had clashed with the doctor answering the phones at the clinic where I work. She had requested the referral, but had gotten upset when he started asking questions about her back pain. When he insisted that she come to the clinic to be examined, she told him he was wasting her time and hung up.

headline.main: Even Doctor-Patient Relationships Can Be Dysfunctional

docs.abstract: Dr Sandeep Jauhar Essay on dysfunctional doctor-patient relationships; some patients described as 'difficult' are seen dependent, entitled, manipulative and self-destructive; some patients have personality traits that kindle aversion, fear, despair and downright malice in doctors; some doctor-patient relationships are dysfunctional simply because of idiosyncracies of doctor and patient: neither is bad, they are just bad together; doctors cannot dismiss their patients, at least not easily; American Medical Assn and courts have set guidelines for when doctor can dismiss patient, and usually only the most egregious misbehavior qualiifies, including threats, violence and noncompliance (M)
